subsection.title: Differentiability
subsection.p: A function is differentiable at points where the derivative is defined. Alternatively, because the derivative at a point represents the slope of the tangent line, we say the function is differentiable at a point wherever the function has a well-defined tangent line.

statement.p: A function f is differentiable at a if f'(a) exists, or more precisely the limit \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(a+h)-f(a)}{h} = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a} exists.

subsection.p: A function is not differentiable if the limit does not exist. There are several reasons this might occur. The first reason is if the function is not continuous.

statement.p: If f is differentiable at a, then f must be continuous at a. Equivalently, if f is not continuous, then f must not be differentiable.

proof.p: Suppose that f is differentiable at a. This means that f'(a) is a value defined by \lim_{x \to a}\frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a} = f'(a). We also know that \lim_{x \to a}[x-a] = a-a = 0. Using the product rule (LC:Product), this implies \lim_{x \to a} [f(x)-f(a)] = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a} \cdot (x-a) = f'(a) \cdot 0 = 0. Because \displaystyle \lim_{x \to a} f(a) = f(a) (LE:Constant), we know that \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = \lim_{x \to a} [f(x)-f(a) + f(a)] = 0 + f(a) = f(a) using the sum rule (LC:Sum). Therefore, f is continuous at a.

subsection.p: Another way that a function might not have be differentiable is where it is continuous but has a corner. This means that the slope at the point looks different from either of the two sides. Mathematically, if we computed the one-sided limits for the formula of the derivative, we would get two different values.

statement.p: Consider the piecewise function defined by f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2, & x \le 1, \\ x, & x \gt 1.\end{cases} Determine if f is differentiable at x=1.

solution.p: This function is continuous because the limit on the left and the limit on the right are equal to the value of the function at x=1, as follows: \lim_{x \to 1^-}f(x) &= \lim_{x \to 1}x^2 = 1^2 = 1, \lim_{x \to 1^+}f(x) &= \lim_{x \to 1}x = 1 = 1, f(1) &= 1^2 = 1.

Now that we know the function is continuous, we can think about the functions to the left and right, f_\ell(x)=x^2 and f_r(x)=x, respectively. Because f_\ell'(x)=2x, we know that \lim_{h \to 0^-} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} = f_\ell'(1) = 2. Similarly, because f_r'(x)=1, we know that \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} = f_r'(1)=1. Since the left and right limits are different, we conclude that \displaystyle \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(1+h)-f(1)}{h} does not exist and f is not differentiable at x=1. The figure below illustrates this graph, showing that there is a corner at x=1.

statement.p: Consider the piecewise function defined by f(x) = \begin{cases} x^2-3x+8 & x \lt 2, \\ 5x-x^2, & x \ge 2.\end{cases} Determine if f is differentiable at x=2.

solution.p: This function is continuous because the limit on the left and the limit on the right are equal to the value of the function at x=2, as follows: \lim_{x \to 2^-}f(x) &= \lim_{x \to 2}(x^2-3x+8) = 2^2-3(2)+8 = 6, \lim_{x \to 2^+}f(x) &= \lim_{x \to 2}(5x-x^2) = 5(2)-2^2 = 6, f(2) &= 5(2)-2^2 = 6.

Now that we know the function is continuous, we can think about the functions to the left and right, f_\ell(x)=x^2-3x+8 and f_r(x)=5x-x^2, respectively. Because f_\ell'(x)=2x-3, we know that \lim_{h \to 0^-} \frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h} = f_\ell'(2) = 2(2)-3=1. Similarly, because f_r'(x)=5-2x, we know that \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h} = f_r'(2)=5-2(2)=1. Since the left and right limits are the same, we conclude that \displaystyle \lim_{h \to 0}\frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h} = 1 and f'(2)=1. So f is differentiable at x=2. The graph of this function has the two parabolas join smoothly with no corner at x=2.

subsection.title: Consequences of Differentiability
subsection.p: There are a number of important consequences of a function being differentiable. These consequences are stated as mathematical theorems that you will need to know by name. We begin by introducing terminology about local extreme values.

statement.p: A function f has a local maximum at a point x=a if f(a) \ge f(x) for all x in a neighborhood of a. It has a local minimum at x=a if f(a) \le f(x) for all x in a neighborhood of a.

subsection.p: The first theorem is about the slope at a local extreme. It guarantees that a local extreme can only occur where the function either is not differentiable or has a horizontal tangent line.

statement.p: If f has a local extreme at x=a and f'(a) exists, then f'(a)=0.

subsection.p: The second theorem combines the Extreme Value Theorem with Fermat's Theorem. If a function is continuous on a closed interval [a,b], then it must achieve both a maximum and a minimum value. If that function has f(a)=f(b), then one of the extreme values must occur inside the interval at some point c \in (a,b). If the function is also differentiable, then we must have f'(c)=0. This result is named Rolle's theorem.

statement.p: If f is continuous on [a,b] and differentiable on (a,b) and f(a)=f(b), then there must be some value c \in (a,b) so that f'(c)=0.

subsection.p: The consequence of Rolle's theorem is that if a function starts and ends at the same value over an interval, it must turn around somewhere. For a differentiable function, the slope at that point must be f'(c)=0.

The third theorem about differentiability applies Rolle's theorem to say something about the average rate of change. Recall that the average rate of change, \left.\frac{\Delta f}{\Delta x}\right|_{[a,b]} = \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}, is the slope of the line, called a secant line, that joins the points (a,f(a)) and (b,f(b)). The Mean Value Theorem guarantees that a continuous and differentiable function will have some point at which the tangent line has the same slope as the secant line over the interval.

statement.p: If f is continuous on [a,b] and differentiable on (a,b), then there must be some value c \in (a,b) so that f'(c)=\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}. Alternatively, we sometimes rewrite this as f(b)-f(a)=f'(c) \cdot (b-a).

proof.p: Let s(x) be the linear function corresponding to this secant line and then define g(x)=f(x)-s(x). Since s(a)=f(a) and s(b)=f(b), we have g(a)=g(b)=0. If f is continuous and differentiable, then so is g. Rolle's theorem guarantees that g'(c)=f'(c)-s'(c) = 0 for some value c \in (a,b). Thus, f'(c)=\left.\frac{\Delta f}{\Delta x}\right|_{[a,b]}.
